questions.text: Which of the following pathological conditions involves the accumulation of pigments through exogenous sources?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Coal worker’s pneumoconiosis

Explanation:

Among the given options, coal workers' pneumoconiosis involves the accumulation of pigments through exogenous sources.

  • Pigments in pathology

    • Endogenous pigments → produced inside the body (melanin, hemosiderin, bilirubin, lipofuscin).

    • Exogenous pigments → come from outside (carbon, dust, tattoo ink).

  • Pneumoconiosis

    • Lung disease due to inhalation & deposition of exogenous dust particles.

    • Most common form → Coal workers’ pneumoconiosis (Anthracosis).

  • Anthracosis (Black Lung Disease)

    • Caused by the accumulation of carbon particles in alveolar macrophages (“dust cells”).

    • Called Black Lung because the lungs appear black from heavy carbon deposition.

    • The term Anthracosis comes from “Anthrakos” (Greek = coal/charcoal).

questions.text: A 83-year-old man presents to his gastroenterologist with complaints of fatigue and discomfort in the upper abdomen. He has a history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus, for which he takes medications regularly. On physical examination, the liver edge is palpable below the right costal margin, indicating hepatomegaly. Laboratory investigations reveal mildly elevated liver enzymes. Which of the following pigments is most likely responsible for the brown discolouration of the liver observed in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Lipofuscin

Explanation:

An 83-year-old man presents with fatigue and upper abdominal discomfort, and physical examination reveals hepatomegaly; mildly elevated liver enzymes are noted on lab tests, and the brown discoloration of the liver is most likely due to the pigment Lipofuscin.

  • Lipofuscin, also known as lipochrome or wear-and-tear pigment, is an insoluble pigment derived from the peroxidation of polyunsaturated lipids in intracellular membranes.
  • It is a telltale sign of free radical injury and lipid peroxidation.
  • It is responsible for the brown atrophy of the liver and heart, where lipofuscin accumulates in the hepatocytes and cardiac myocytes, respectively, due to oxidative damage and impaired cellular turnover, particularly with increasing age.
  • It is also seen in senile atrophy (pigment of the old age).
  • In histopathological examination, it appears as a yellow-brown, finely granular cytoplasmic pigment, often deposited in the perinuclear region.
  • The special stain used for lipofuscin is Oil red O and Acid-fast / Ziehl–Neelsen stain.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with a painless, slow-growing, pigmented lesion on her back with irregular borders and varying shades of brown and black. Excisional biopsy of the lesion is performed, and histopathological examination reveals nests of melanocytes within the dermis, with prominent melanin pigment deposition. Which of the following staining techniques would be most suitable for visualization of the melanin pigment within the melanocytes in this patient's biopsy specimen?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Masson Fontana stain

Explanation:

A 45-year-old woman presents with a painless, slow-growing pigmented lesion on her back characterized by irregular borders and varying shades of brown and black; histopathological examination of an excisional biopsy reveals nests of melanocytes in the dermis with prominent melanin deposition, best visualized using the Masson-Fontana stain.

  • Best for seeing the amount & distribution of melanin pigment (inside/outside melanocytes)-Masson–Fontana stain

  • Other methods:

    • Schmorl’s stain → also for melanin pigment.

    • Enzymatic method (DOPA oxidase test) → best test for melanin production capacity.

    • Immunohistochemistry (for melanocytes / pigment-producing cells):

      • HMB-45

      • Melan-A (Option D ruled out)

      • It is a marker for melanocytes and melanoma cells and is particularly useful in distinguishing melanocytic lesions from other types of skin tumours or metastatic cancers.
      • On the other side, Masson Fontana staining helps to assess the extent of melanin production within tumors. (Option D ruled out)

  • Key distinction:

    • Pigment visualization → Masson–Fontana

    • Cell identification (melanocytes) → HMB-45, Melan-A

 

 

 

 

Masson Trichome stain (Option B): Masson Trichrome stain primarily differentiates between collagen and smooth muscle fibres.

 

Periodic-Acid-Schiff (PAS) stain (Option C): Periodic Acid-Schiff (PAS) stain detects carbohydrates such as glycogen and mucin.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with complaints of fatigue, joint pain, and abdominal discomfort. On examination, he exhibits bronze-coloured skin pigmentation mainly on the face and hands. Laboratory tests reveal elevated serum ferritin levels and transferrin saturation. Which of the following staining techniques would be most appropriate to visualize hemosiderin deposition in tissues in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Perl’s stain

Explanation:

A 45-year-old man presents with fatigue, joint pain, and abdominal discomfort, along with bronze-colored skin pigmentation on the face and hands; laboratory tests show elevated serum ferritin and transferrin saturation, and the most appropriate staining technique to visualize tissue hemosiderin deposition in this patient is Perls' stain.

  • Perl's stain, also known as Prussian Blue stain is the stain used to detect hemosiderin.
  • Gold standard for Fe³⁺ iron (gives blue color).
  • The given clinical scenario suggests the patient is suffering from Hemochromatosis, an iron overload disorder in which excessive iron is deposited in various tissues as hemosiderin, a golden yellow to brown, granular, or crystalline pigment.

 

Lillie's stain (Option B): Lillie's stain also known as Lillie-Mayer's hematoxylin-eosin stain might help in detecting Ferrous ions (Fe2+) but is not useful for hemosiderin, which is ferric iron (Fe3+)

Rhodanine stain (Option C): Rhodanine is utilized as a selective stain for the detection and localization of copper ions that accumulate in tissues such as the liver and brain in copper metabolism disorders, such as Wilson's disease (not to be confused with Rhodamine in microbiology for Mycobacterium TB).

 

Supravital stains (Option D): Supravital stains are a group of dyes used to stain living cells or tissues without causing cell death. New methylene blue and Brilliant cresyl blue target ribonucleic acid residues in reticulocytes and provide the characteristic blue reticular staining pattern.

questions.text: Which of the following pathological conditions is associated with the 'Tabby cat' effect?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Diphtheria myocarditis

Explanation:

Diphtheria myocarditis is associated with the 'Tabby Cat' Effect.

  • Fat accumulation in the heart gives a characteristic Tigroid or Tabby cat appearance, which appears as yellowish streaks (fatty change) alternating with reddish streaks (unaffected myocardium).
  • This appearance is seen in conditions such as
    • Diphtheria myocarditis
    • Arrhythmogenic Right Ventricular Cardiomyopathy (ARVCM)
    • Cell injury.

 

Xanthomas (Option B): Xanthomas are found in skin and in tendons.

Cholesterolosis (Option C): Cholesterolosis refers to the cholesterol-laden macrophages in the lamina propria of the gallbladder aka strawberry gallbladder.

Fatty liver (Option D): Fatty liver, also known as hepatic steatosis, is characterized by the abnormal accumulation of triglycerides within hepatocytes (liver cells).

questions.text: Which of the following stains is not typically employed for the detection of lipid accumulation in histological samples?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Toluidine blue

Explanation:

Toluidine Blue is not typically employed for the detection of lipid accumulation in histological samples.

  • A special stain for Mast cells and Basophils. 
  • It is a metachromatic stain
    • Solution - Blue coloured
    • Colour stained to mast cells and basophils - Purple

Stains for fat

  • Oil Red O (Option C)
  • Sudan Black B (Option A)
  • Sudan IV (Option B)
  • Osmium Tetroxide

Note: Toluidine Blue is a special stain for Mast cells and Basophils.

questions.text:
A 60-year-old woman presents with bone pain and tenderness over her lower back. Imaging reveals multiple lytic lesions in the vertebral column. Laboratory tests indicate anaemia, elevated serum calcium levels, and monoclonal gammopathy. A bone marrow biopsy confirms plasma cell proliferation. Microscopic examination of the biopsy reveals intracellular inclusions, as shown in the image. What is the composition of the intracellular inclusions marked in the image?



{{caption_text}}
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Accumulations of immunoglobulins

 

Explanation:

The clinical presentation is highly suggestive of multiple myeloma, a plasma cell dyscrasia characterized by bone pain, lytic lesions, anaemia, hypercalcemia, and monoclonal gammopathy.

Microscopic examination of the bone marrow biopsy may reveal the presence of intracellular inclusions, such as Russell bodies (Immunoglobulins in the cytoplasm) and Dutcher bodies (containing Ig in the nucleus), within some plasma cells.

questions.text: Following the resection of the pituitary adenoma in a patient with Cushing's disease, which intracellular change is most likely in residual adenoma cells?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Crooke hyaline change


Explanation:

Following resection of a pituitary adenoma in a patient with Cushing's disease, the most likely intracellular change observed in the residual adenoma cells is Crooke's Hyaline Change.

  • It is a histopathological finding seen in the pituitary gland, particularly in corticotroph adenomas associated with Cushing's disease.
  • In crooke hyaline change, the normal granular, basophilic cytoplasm of ACTH-producing cells becomes homogenous and paler due to the accumulation of intermediate cytokeratin (CK) filaments.
  • These changes occur as a response to chronic hypercortisolism.

 

 

Mallory-Denk bodies (Option A): Mallory-Denk bodies or Mallory hyaline bodies are eosinophilic, intracytoplasmic inclusions composed of intermediate filaments, particularly cytokeratin 8 and 18, commonly seen in hepatocytes in conditions such as alcoholic liver disease.

Lewy bodies (Option B): Lewy bodies are eosinophilic intracytoplasmic inclusions composed of aggregated alpha-synuclein protein and are characteristic of neurodegenerative disorders such as Parkinson's disease and Lewy body dementia.

 

Civatte bodies (Option D): They are also known as Colloid Bodies/ Cytoid Bodies and are seen in Lichen Planus.

questions.text: Which of the following stains would be most appropriate for visualizing glycogen deposits?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Periodic acid-Schiff (PAS) stain

Explanation:

Periodic acid-Schiff (PAS) stain would be most appropriate for visualizing glycogen deposits, among the given options.

  • Glycogen is PAS +ve; Diastase sensitive

Hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) stain (Option A) is a basic stain that stains nuclei blue-purple (hematoxylin) and cytoplasm and extracellular matrix pink (eosin). While it can highlight muscle fibre morphology, it does not specifically stain glycogen.

Masson's trichrome stain (Option C): is used to distinguish collagen fibers, which stain blue, from other tissue components; it stains muscle fibers red, collagen blue, and nuclei blue-black, but it is not specific for detecting glycogen

Oil Red O stain (Option D) is used to detect lipids and fat droplets.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect about dystrophic calcification?

choices.text: It occurs in damaged or necrotic tissues.
It is characterized by the deposition of calcium salts in normal tissues.
It is often seen in areas of chronic inflammation.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) It is characterized by the deposition of calcium salts in normal tissues

Explanation:

Calcium deposition is in dead or degenerating tissues.

 

Dystrophic Calcification

Metastatic Calcification

  • There will be a normal blood calcium count.(Optin D ruled out)

Some examples:

  • Atheroma
  • Monckeberg Sclerosis

It is also called calcific medial degeneration.

  • It happens in the tunica media.
  • Calcium occurs blue in color
  • It occurs only as an old age phenomenon without any clinical significance.

Psammoma Bodies:

  • Seen in:

  • Normal tissues are seen.

questions.text: Which of the following case scenarios is not indicative of metastatic calcification?

choices.text: A 60-year-old male with a history of chronic renal failure presented with shortness of breath and bilateral lung opacities on chest X-ray.
A 45-year-old female with spinal tuberculosis complained of back pain.
A 30-year-old male with a long-standing history of heavy milk and calcium carbonate intake now experiencing recurrent kidney stones.
A 55-year-old female with sarcoidosis demonstrated elevated levels of serum vitamin D and calcium.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) A 45-year-old female with spinal tuberculosis complaining of back pain.

Explanation:

In tuberculosis, tissue death and degeneration lead to dystrophic calcification, which occurs despite normal serum calcium levels.

  • Tuberculosis can lead to dystrophic calcification in bone tissue, resulting in symptoms such as bone pain and fractures.
  • Metastatic calcification → elevated serum calcium
  • Dystrophic calcification → normal serum calcium, dead/degenerating tissue

There are four principal causes of hypercalcemia:

  1. Increased secretion of parathyroid hormone (PTH) with subsequent bone resorption, as in hyperparathyroidism due to parathyroid tumours, and ectopic secretion of PTH-related protein by malignant tumours
  2. Resorption of bone tissue, secondary to primary tumours of bone marrow (e.g., multiple myeloma, leukaemia) or diffuse skeletal metastasis (e.g., breast cancer), accelerated bone turnover (e.g., Paget disease), or immobilization.
  3. Vitamin D–related disorders, including vitamin D intoxication, sarcoidosis (in which macrophages activate a vitamin D precursor), and idiopathic hypercalcemia of infancy (Williams syndrome), characterized by abnormal sensitivity to vitamin D (Option D ruled out)
  4. Renal failure, which causes phosphate retention, leads to secondary hyperparathyroidism. (Option A ruled out)

A 30-year-old male with a long-standing history of heavy milk and calcium carbonate intake now experiencing recurrent kidney stones (Option C): This will lead to increased serum calcium levels whereas dystrophic calcification occurs despite normal calcium levels.

questions.text: Which staining technique is commonly used to visualize calcium deposits in tissues and is particularly useful for detecting minute amounts of calcium?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Alizarin Red S stain

Explanation:

Alizarin Red S Stain is commonly used to visualize calcium deposits in tissues and is particularly useful for detecting minute amounts of calcium, giving red color to calcium deposits.

Stains of Calcium:

  • Von Kossa Stain
    • Imparts black color to calcium.
  • Alizarin Red S
    • Imparts red color to calcium.
    • Used for staining minor amounts of calcium.

  • Calcein
    • Fluorescent stain for calcium
  • Azan Stain
    • To differentiate mineralized bone from osteoid.

 

Masson’s trichrome (Option A): To differentiate collagen (blue) and muscle fibers (red).

Prussian blue (Option B): Used for staining Iron.

Wright-Giemsa stain (Option D): Used for hematology slides.
